Dude, are you actually reading what I wrote? If this channel were about PR faux-pas then maybe you'd be right. But in a channel which discusses and promotes reason itself, yelling "haha, they set themselves up for non-reasoning people" seems off-topic, and even childish. Besides, who do they care about, their readers or their critics? Their readers aren't going to yell irony. They're going to say "yeah! and we're the one outlet that doesn't fall to that standard". Their critics? Who cares?

And again, your analogy doesn't fit. Graphically reminding your customer that there is death and suffering required for their purchase doesn't compare to potential hypocrisy.

@freekzero
After a career in sales and marketing, I suspect that my opinions on this might be a bit more reasonable than most. In the area that TF was discussing - how things play with an audience - the intelligent choice is most often based on image and not logic.

For example, one of the prime software products I used and resold in designing and implementing business process automation was made by a small company, but was by far the best product on the market in it's niche. It was also less than 1/4 the cost of the far inferior Adobe solution in the same market.

Logic would tell you that Adobe should never have been able to beat us head to head - but with large corporations and government agencies, they often did. The solution this software company came up with was to triple their price with the next point release. There were no important upgrades or value adds in that release - the only serious change was the price. Sales more than doubled that year.

This is because the image put forth by our low price was that this was not truly enterprise level software.

This is much the same - the image contradicts the narrative, and the image is usually more important.

You keep going off on what I would say borders on tangents. Sure image is important in success in this imperfect world. That doesn't change two facts: 1. That TF (to my understanding) is not about image and pointing out when other people get shallow imagery wrong 2. (and again I repeat) That there is nothing wrong with ONE media outlet who isn't prone to X saying the WHOLE industry is dominated by X. The only thing wrong with it is their detractors can point out the shallow, meaningless, apparent hypocrisy for equally shallow and non-thinking listeners to buy into. If TF is just pointing out that HP is themselves guilty of the same type of shallow imagery faux pas that they often point out in others... well that's a pretty lame point, and most certainly not worthy of all the anticipation he builds up. So what am I missing? Or did TF just choose to be his opponent on this one?

@freekzero But what he said, almost word for word is that they were stupid to show an image of an all female editorial staff while touting sex discrimination in media. Are you saying that he said that, but meant something different?

Yes, that is what he meant as far as I can tell, but I think that was a bad conclusion. It was only stupid in that it gives a soundbite to throw against them, one with no actual weight or meaning. Even if we assume their all-female board is the result of sexual discrimination (which we don't know, no more than anyone seeing a male dominated editorial board at another outlet is the result of discrimination) few are likely to have an issue with that. No more than have an issue with BET when there is no WET channel. And again, those that do, already dislike them, so where's the harm? It just seems like a weak point at best.

@freekzero Stupid marketing is stupid marketing - period. It doesn't matter if net immigration from Mexico has been zero for almost ten years, and that a wall would only create a market for ladders - Trump knows how to push buttons and his stupid wall promise works. In English "man" represents both the masculine and the neutral as where " woman" explicitly represents the feminine. By using a female term with a male term also forces the masculine context instead of the neutral. For example if I walk into a room of people and say; "hey guys! how is everyone!" I clearly mean the crowd and not the males exclusively. However if I say; "hey guys and gals!" then I am distinctly addressing both genders. There are many examples of this in English. Perhaps the most common is "mankind", which tends to imply humanity as a whole, as opposed to "womankind" which means women exclusively. In this case, though, it is simply a colloquial expression. commentThread.commentText: I couldn't quite point out why I stopped dealing with the Huffington Post around 2012-2013, but some time apart and their continued trend really cleared that up for me. Who knows...  with this all women board, HuffPo might Sam Brick itself.

I don't get how someone can sit down at the end of the day, having written an article about how great it is that emojis now have greater representation (a shallow concern within an even more shallow form of medium), and not realize that they're a black hole of human productivity. Look at some of these degrees you see modern feminists getting, the articles you see them writing, and really ask yourself: "Could this provide a tangible benefit to the advancement of mankind?", and the answer is almost always a resounding no. PhD's on Lady Gaga and Twilight, Master's degrees written on the tv-watching habits of 10-13 year olds, "Iceberg research is sexist" articles... it's basically just throwing money and resources into a pit and burning them. I'm a reproductive endocrinologist working on stress hormones in fish, and I often wonder whether my research is worth a damn or not, but the silver lining is that I can always go "Well, maybe it'll be important for boosting yields in aquaculture some day". I feel like if I were to be sitting on my deathbed looking back on my life, and the highlight of my early career was "I voiced my opinion to others on a complete non-issue and told harder working more intelligent people to feel bad for how they had it better than me", I'd be compelled to pull the plug on my life support.
